ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
1) Insight into historical and religious contexts of Vedic Sanskrit and Vedic corpus 
2) Close, detailed analysis of the differences between Vedic and classical Sanskrit  syntactic, morphological, and lexical
3) accordingly, knowledge of the history of Sanskrit

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A particular strength was Dr. Uskokovs patient elucidation of forms and how they are generated. For any peculiar form, he could provide a detailed explanation of the reasons why it looked the way it did, helping instill a trust in the coherence of the language and building linguistic knowledge. Beginning with Upanisads before turning to more difficult material from Rig Veda also helped ease us into the interpretative and linguistic difficulties of Vedic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Wholeheartedly. Anyone with an interest in Sanskrit, in the Vedas, or in Indian history should take this course.
